data.text: Contents

Undertaking a risk assessment after notifying either the adult or children's safeguarding teams ............................................................................................................. 9

Accuracy of information and the use of Interpreters ................................................... 12  Observing the partner or family member if present during the consultation ................ 12
Introduction

It is illegal in the UK (1) to subject a girl or woman to female genital mutilation (FGM) or to assist a non-UK person to carry out FGM overseas. For the purpose of the criminal law in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, FGM is defined as all procedures involving partial or total removal of the external female genitalia or other injury to the female genital organs, whether for cultural or other non-therapeutic reasons. Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is responsible for ensuring the provision of sufficient, safe and high quality health service which meets the needs of survivors in partnership with other multi agency services, and to identify and act upon the identification of FGM in accordance with local and national legislation and guidance.
(Refer to appendix 1)

FGM is a deeply rooted tradition, widely practised mainly among specific ethnic populations in Africa and parts of the Middle East and Asia. The World Health Organisation estimates that between  and  million girls and women worldwide have experienced female genital mutilation and around 3 million girls undergo some form of the procedure each year in Africa alone. FGM has been documented also in Iraq, Israel, Oman, the United Arab Emirates, the Occupied Palestinian Territories, India, Indonesia, Malaysia and Pakistan.
The prevalence of FGM in the UK is hard to estimate because of the hidden nature of the crime. However, a recent study (2) estimated that:
Approximately 60,000 girls aged 0-14 were born in England and Wales to mothers who had undergone FGM;

Approximately 103,000 women aged 15-49 and approximately 24,000 women aged 50 and over who have migrated to England and Wales are living with the consequences of FGM. In addition, approximately 10,000 girls under 15 who have migrated to England and Wales are likely to have undergone FGM.
(For a list of communities where FGM is prevalent refer to appendix 2)
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

Provide support and advice to professionals who have responsibility to safeguard children and protect adults from the abuse associated with female genital mutilation and to ensure the necessary risk assessments are completed.

To ensure staff are aware of the law: Female genital mutilation is illegal in this country as per the Female Genital Mutilation Act 2013 (3) (this offence captures mutilation of a females labia majora, labia minora or clitoris), except on specific physical and mental health grounds (see www.fco.gov.uk/fgm). Under the 2003 Act, a person is guilty of an offence if they excise, infibulate or otherwise mutilate the whole or any part of a girl's or woman's labia majora or clitoris, except for the necessary operations performed by a registered medical practitioner or a midwife (or a person undergoing training with a view of becoming a medical practitioner or a midwife) on a woman who is in labour or has just given birth, for the purpose connected, with the labour or birth (these exceptions are set out in section 1(2) and (3) of the Act).
To ensure all staff are made aware of their regulatory duty to report FGM under the Serious Crime Act 2015.
Definitions

table_items.text: Female Genital Mutilation is classified into four major types (8)

FGM is a collective term for illegal procedures which include the removal of part and or all external female genitalia for cultural or other non-therapeutic reasons. The practice is not required by any religion and is medically unnecessary, painful and has serious health consequences (See appendix 1) at the time it is carried out and in later life. The procedure is typically performed on girls at any age, but is also performed on newborn infants and young women before marriage or pregnancy. A number of girls die as a direct result of the procedure, from blood loss or infection. FGM may be practised illegally by doctors or traditional health workers in the UK, or girls may be sent abroad for the operation.

Clitoridectomy: partial or total removal of the clitoris (a small, sensitive and erectile part of the female genitals) and, in very rare cases, only the prepuce (the fold of skin surrounding the clitoris).
Excision: partial or total removal of the clitoris and the labia minora, with, or without excision of the labia majora (the labia are the ‘'lips'' that surround the vagina).

Infibulation: narrowing of the vaginal opening through the creation of a covering seal. The seal is formed by cutting and repositioning the inner, or outer, labia, with or without removal of the clitoris.
Other: all other harmful procedures to the female genitalia for non- medical purposes e.g. pricking, incising, scraping and cauterizing the genital area.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities within the Trust
The Trust is committed to ensure and promote the safety of women and children.
Adult & Children Safeguarding Committee Responsibilities are:
Monitoring the reporting of FGM.
Be assured that staff are aware of, and work to, local and national guidance for the prevention and reporting of FGM.
Provide assurance to the Joint Executive Committee FGM identification and reporting procedures are in place and being adhered to.
Monitoring of Trust Safeguarding Strategic Plan, including actions referring to FGM.

Safeguarding Operational Groups are responsible for ensuring the Trust has an agreed FGM action plan and FGM policies and procedures are operationally in place. Individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive)
Duties of individuals within the Trust Duties Are:
To identify when a girl or young woman may be at risk of FGM and respond and report appropriately;
To identify when a girl or woman has had FGM and respond and report appropriately;
All staff are responsible for knowing and adhering to the legal requirements for the reporting of FGM.

To be aware that the reporting of FGM is a mandatory duty: A mandatory reporting duty for FGM requires regulated health and social care professionals and teachers in England and Wales to report known cases of FGM in under 18- year-olds to the police (Mandatory Reporting of Female Genital Mutilation – Procedural Information, Home Office 2015);

To establish information required to inform a risk assessment. Staff must ensure that any interpreter should be appropriately trained in relation to FGM and should not be a family member; not be known to the woman and or family; and not be an individual in the woman's community.
Any female child born to a woman who has been subjected to FGM must be considered to be at risk, as must other female children in the extended family.

4.2.1 The Managing Director is responsible for ensuring that all care and interventions provided by Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust are within the law and respects the Human Rights of each individual. The named person within Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust with responsibility for this policy is the Director of Nursing.

4.2.2 The Site Medical Director is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all medical and dental staff are able to comply with the contents of this document. In addition, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the monitoring and audit of this document is undertaken and reported in the appropriate forum as indicated in this document.

4.2.3 The Site Director of Nursing is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all non-medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
4.2.4 General Managers are responsible for ensuring staff are aware of and have access to this policy that staff are released for training and are appropriately supported to implement this policy.
4.2.5 The Safeguarding Named Nurse, Midwife and Doctor for Adults and Children are responsible for:
Ensuring staff are adequately supported to implement this policy including providing advice and assistance in the application of this policy;
For the specialist advice, training and development of safeguarding policies and procedures in relation to safeguarding children and adults;
The Named Professionals are integral to the Trust's clinical governance system. The Named Professionals will ensure that any relevant safeguarding audits.
4.2.6 Head of Midwifery & Gynaecology, Matrons, Ward Mangers, Co-Ordinators are responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the hospital.
4.2.7 Adult & Children's Safeguarding Teams

To provide support and guidance to staff in the protection of individuals at risk. To provide assurance to the safeguarding committee that staff have received the appropriate training and are adhering to Local and National FGM guidance.
Professional sensitivity
Health care professionals need to be sensitive to the fact that women and families may have been under intense cultural/social pressure within their country of origin to practice FGM.
Health care professionals need to consider how to discuss FGM with sensitivity and without being judgemental.
Reporting under safeguarding procedures
(Refer to appendix 3, 4 and 5)
Any staff member that suspects an adult or child has been subjected to or is at risk of FGM should seek immediate advice from the adults or children's safeguarding teams.
6.1.1 The aim of reporting is to make an initial assessment of risk, and then support the on-going assessment of women and children at risk.

6.1.2 The Trust also has a duty to provide FGM notification data. Appendix 4 should be completed and sent to the Adult or Children's Safeguarding Teams. Please note, this is a data collection form. Although the information may be helpful to inform the risk assessment, it is not a referral. Advice should be sort from the safeguarding team and a referral should be made to the appropriate social care team if appropriate using the safeguarding referral procedures.
Initial enquiry by staff member
(Refer to appendix 3 and 5)

Initial enquiry should be by assessing for physical indicators, the healthcare professional might need to rely on just disclosure in the first instance. So asking the right questions is important. To enquire about FGM the following questions should be answered:
Do you or your partner come from a community where cutting or circumcision is practised?
Have you been cut? It may be appropriate to use another term or phrase.
Undertaking a risk assessment after notifying either the adult or
children's safeguarding teams
(Refer to appendix 5)
The risk assessment should then inform a proportionate multi-agency response and protection plan.

The Information Standards Board 2014/2015 (9) requires requires that MSE Group of Hospitals record all information all information about FGM within its patient population in the healthcare records and reports monthly to Health and Social Care.
The risk assessment framework is to support the health professional to identify and consider risks relating to FGM, and to support the discussion with the child, woman and family.

It should be used to assess whether the patient you are treating is either at risk of harm or has had FGM and whether your patient has children who could potentially be at risk of FGM or if there are other children in the family/close friends who may be at risk.
The assessment and the information obtained must be recorded within the patient's healthcare records.
Once the assessment has been completed the staff member must use the risk assessment to make the following decisions:
Is a referral required: is the referral urgent (individual is at immediate risk) or is it a non-urgent referral?
Is safeguarding advice required from the Trust Safeguarding Teams, Social Care or the Police?

Has the risk altered, or is the risk is at a point where a referral to an external body is required? Document in the healthcare records and share the information about your decision making process appropriately.
An urgent referral, if required, should be made out of hours if necessary, as this will allow the police to collect physical evidence should it be required.

Urgent referrals should be made if the healthcare professional believes that there are plans to travel abroad imminently, which present a risk to a child and is likely to undergo FGM if allowed to leave your care.

In urgent cases, Children's Social Care and the Police will consider what action to take, including the consideration of an Emergency Protection Order (EPO).If required an EPO is made under Section 44 of the Children's Act 1989(5) enabling the child to be removed to a place of safety.
The assessment frameworks are for guidance. The healthcare professional should always still seek guidance from the safeguarding teams.
Considerations for pregnant women
When FGM is disclosed by a pregnant woman to a midwife a referral will be made to the obstetric consultant lead for FGM to make a safe delivery plan for Mother and Baby
At the birth of a child, when a family history of FGM has been identified, this information should be recorded in the Personal Child Health Record Book and the Health Visitor informed.
The Maternity Unit Discharge Records must include if the mother has FGM and state that the information has been shared with the patient's General Practitioner and Health Visitor.
A female child born to a mother who has under gone FGM must be entered on the FGM-IS system by the safeguarding team.

The Information Standards Board 2014/2015 (9) requires that MSE Group of Hospitals record all information about FGM within its patient population in the healthcare records and report monthly to Health and Social Care.
Suspicion of intended FGM or actual FGM of a child must be
referred to Children's Social Care.

FGM is not an issue that can be decided on by personal preference - it is illegal, extremely harmful and a form of child abuse and violence against women and girls. If any child (under 18) or vulnerable adult has symptoms or signs of FGM, or if the health professional has good reason to suspect the individual is at risk of FGM having considered the family history or other relevant factors, then the individual must be referred using the existing safeguarding procedures.

Additionally, when a patient is identified as being at risk of FGM, this information must be shared with the General Practitioner and Health Visitor as part of safeguarding actions (see Section  of the 1989 Children's Act(5)).
As from October 31st 2015 a mandatory duty has been introduced through the Serious Crime Act  (4) to report cases of FGM.
The mandatory duty will:
Apply in cases of known FGM i.e. instances which are disclosed by the victim and or are visually confirmed.
Be limited to girls under 18.
Apply to all regulated healthcare and social care professionals, and teachers.

Require reports to be made to the police within one month of initial disclosure/identification - depending on the circumstances of the case, will not necessarily trigger automatic arrests; the police will then work with the relevant agencies to ensure an appropriate safeguarding response is put in place which places the interest of the child at the centre.
Failure to comply with the mandatory duty will be dealt with via existing disciplinary measures, which may include referral to the professional regulator as appropriate.
Accuracy of information and the use of Interpreters
The health care professional should ensure that an interpreter is available, as this will be required for many appointments.

The interpreter should be an authorised accredited interpreter and should not be a family member, not be known to the individual, and not be an individual with influence in the individual's community.
Observing the partner or family member if present during the
consultation

If a woman or child is accompanied by a partner or parent/guardian respectively, the health professional must be vigilant and aware of the signs of coercion and control as detailed by the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS)
http:/www.cps.gov.uk/publications/equality/domesticviolence.htm in the Serious Crime Act 2015(4). Identifying these characteristics will assist in the risk assessment.
Additional safeguarding duties for the protection of children at risk
or subjected to FGM.

A child for whom FGM is planned is likely to suffer significant harm through physical abuse and emotional abuse, which is categorised by some as sexual abuse. Any information or concern that a child is at immediate risk of, or has undergone, female genital mutilation should result in a child protection referral to local authority children's social care in line with local safeguarding children procedures/SET guidelines.

Where a child is thought to be at risk of FGM, practitioners should be alert to the need to act quickly - before the child is abused through the FGM procedure in the UK or taken abroad to undergo the procedure.

On receipt of a referral, a strategy meeting/discussion must be convened within two working days, and should involve representatives from the police, local authority children's social care, education, health and third sector services. Health providers or third sector organisations with specific expertise (e.g. FGM, domestic abuse and/or sexual abuse) must be invited, and consideration may also be given to inviting a legal advisor.

Every attempt should be made to work with parents on a voluntary basis to prevent the abuse. It is the duty of the investigating team to look at every possible way that parental co-operation can be achieved, including the use of community organisations and/or community leaders to facilitate the work with parents/family. However, the child's interest is always paramount.
If no agreement is reached, the first priority is protection of the child and the least intrusive legal action should be taken to ensure the child's safety.

If the strategy meeting/discussion decides that the child is in immediate danger of mutilation and parents cannot satisfactorily guarantee that they will not proceed with it, then an emergency protection order should be sought.

If the child has already undergone FGM, the strategy meeting/discussion will need to consider carefully whether to continue enquiries or whether to assess the need for support services. If any legal action is being considered, legal advice must be sought.
A child protection conference should only be considered necessary if there are unresolved child protection issues once the initial investigation and assessment have been completed.

Where FGM has been practised; the Police Child Abuse Investigation Team (CAIT) will take a lead role in the investigation of this serious crime, working to common joint investigative practices and in line with strategy agreements.
Legal proceedings under the Children's Act  (5) should be
considered.
Children's Social Care will inform the Police Child Abuse Investigation Team at the earliest opportunity and convene a Strategy Meeting within two working days. This will be confirmed by Social Care.

The importance of sharing information between practitioners and between agencies in relation to a girl's potential risk of FGM , and in relation to discussions held with family members around safeguarding must not be under-estimated this information is vital to all agencies involved, to inform decisions on what the best course of action is to protect anyone from FGM.

As FGM is a form of child abuse, professionals have a statutory obligation under national safeguarding protocols (e.g. Working Together to Safeguard Children 2013(6)) to protect girls and women at risk of FGM, ensuring that the response to FGM includes the sharing of information with multi-agency partners throughout the girls childhood, and that if, or when, the risk facing the girl changes (which may mean it escalates or even becomes less immediate), this is identified and consideration is given as to whether or not a change in subsequent safeguarding actions are required.

The Department for Education published statutory guidance in 2013 entitled Working Together to Safeguard Children. This guidance should be read and followed by those working in health; whilst the guidance does not make specific provision for safeguarding activities relating to FGM, it sets out requirements around information sharing which are required to effectively safeguard against FGM and all forms of child abuse.

The amendments made to the Female Genital Mutilation Act 2003 (1) and amendments brought through Serious Crime Act 2015 (4) strengthen legislation, however health care professionals are not expected to investigate or make decisions. All cases are dealt with under existing safeguarding frameworks. One specific consideration when putting in place safeguarding measures against FGM is that the potential risk to a girl born in the UK can usually be identified at birth, because through ante-natal care and delivery of the child, NHS professionals can and should have identified that the mother has had FGM. However FGM can be carried out at any age throughout childhood, meaning that identifying FGM at birth can mean that any safeguarding measures adopted may have to be in place for more than  years over the course of the girl's childhood.

Once concerns have been raised about FGM, there should also be a consideration of the potential risk to other girls in the family and practising community. Professionals should be alert to the fact that any one of the girl children amongst these groups could be identified as being at risk of FGM and will need to be responded to as a ‘child in need' or a ‘child in need of protection'.
If the individual is over 18

When treating an adult woman with FGM it should be considered whether she is at risk of further violence, and therefore whether she herself needs protection and support, as well as whether she has any children, whether there are children within her care, or in her extended family or wider network who may need protection.

Once the woman has had the safeguarding requirements considered and acted upon, if it is decided that she as an individual adult is not currently facing risk of further abuse, she should still be offered support should she wish to make a report to the police in relation to her having undergone FGM. Health care professionals should offer this support whether the FGM she may wish to report appears to have been a crime in the UK or another country.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Adult Safeguarding Team and Child Safeguarding Team

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Joint Adult and Child Safeguarding Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local safeguarding guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Hospital's clinical directorates of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 6)

Appendix 1: Consequences of FGM

Many men and women in practising communities can be unaware of the relationship between FGM and its harmful health and welfare consequences as set out below, in particular the longer-term complications affecting sexual intercourse and childbirth.
The short-term consequences following a girl undergoing FGM can include:
severe pain
emotional and psychological shock (exacerbated by having to reconcile being subjected to the trauma by loving parents, extended family and friends) haemorrhage
wound infections, including tetanus and blood borne viruses (including HIV and Hepatitis B and C)
urinary retention
injury to adjacent tissues
fracture or dislocation as a result of restraint
damage to other organs
death.

The longer-term implications for women who have had FGM Types 1 and 2 are likely to be related to the trauma of the actual procedure, whilst health problems caused by FGM Type 3 are more severe and long-lasting.

However, all types of FGM are extremely harmful and cause severe damage to health and wellbeing. World Health Organization research has shown that women who have undergone FGM of all types, but particularly Type 3, are more likely to have complications during childbirth.
The long-term health implications of FGM can include:
chronic vaginal and pelvic infections
difficulties with menstruation
difficulties in passing urine and chronic urine infections
renal impairment and possible renal failure
damage to the reproductive system, including infertility
infibulation cysts, neuromas and keloid scar formation
obstetric fistula
complications in pregnancy and delay in the second stage of childbirth
pain during sex and lack of pleasurable sensation

psychological damage, including a number of mental health and psychosexual problems such as low libido, depression, anxiety and sexual dysfunction; flashbacks during pregnancy and childbirth; substance misuse and/or self-harm
death of mother and child during childbirth
Pregnant women with previous FGM have an increased risk of haemorrhage, perineal
trauma, caesarean section and perinatal death (7)
increased risk of HIV and other sexually transmitted infections

Countries that practice FGM

data.text: Return completed form to the Adult Safeguarding Team, Churchfield 2 or by email to safeguarding.adults@southend.nhs.uk
Appendix 4: Professional duty to report - a practical guide *
The Facts
Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) is child abuse and is against the law
Regulated health and social care professionals and teachers are required to report cases of FGM in girls under 18which they identify in the course of their professional work, to the police

This is a personal duty, the regulated professional who identifies FGM/ receives the disclosure must make the report ( employees who are not regulated do not have to comply with the duty but must follow the safeguarding procedure)
Who Does this Cover
Girls under the age of 18 years who have disclosed that they have had FGM
When signs and symptoms appearing to show that she has had FGM.
If you have no reason to believe that it was for the girls mental of physical health- or for purposes connected to labour or birth
This includes genital piercings and tattoos for none medical reasons.
What do I need to Do
Telephone 101, the none emergency crime number
Discuss with the hospital child/maternity safeguarding professional
Document your actions including the police reference number
Make sure that you or someone with access to all the information is available and prepared to discuss further with the police lead investigator
Discuss with the family
Tell them the report is being made prior to or parallel with making the report unless you believe that this would lead to serious harm to the child or anyone else
When do I need to Call
Call 101 as soon as possible with the same urgency as other safeguarding cases
By the end of the next working day at the latest
The safety of the girl and others are your priority, advice should be taken from the hospital safeguarding team or if out of hours social worker if necessary
What /do I Need to Give the 101 Operator
Your Details
Name
Work contact details, phone number and email address Role
Place of Work
The Girls Details Name
Age
Date of Birth
Details of Hospital's Safeguarding Leads
Paul Hodson Associate director for Safeguarding 01702 435555 ext 5676
Yvonne Shaw Deputy Associate Director for Safeguarding 01702 435555 ext 7062
Sue Kent Named Nurse for Safeguarding 01702 435555 ext 7276
Beth Nakhlah Named Midwife for Safeguarding
Confirm that you have undertaken safeguarding actions
What if I don't Make the Report?
Failure to comply may be considered through your fitness to practice proceedings with your regulator
Regulators will, as with all other matters, consider professionals ability currently to practice safely and account the circumstances of the case
The safety of the girl or other individuals at risk of harm are paramount
